A zero-free interval for chromatic polynomials of graphs with 33NUMBER:33-leaf spanning trees

Abstract

It is proved that if G𝐺italic-GG is a graph containing a spanning tree with at most three leaves, then the chromatic polynomial of G𝐺italic-GG has no roots in the interval (1,t1]1subscript𝑡1OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:](1,t_{1}], where t1≈1.2904subscript𝑡11.2904italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.2904t_{1}\approx 1.2904 is the smallest real root of the polynomial (t-2)6+4⁢(t-1)2⁢(t-2)3-(t-1)4superscript𝑡264superscript𝑡12superscript𝑡23superscript𝑡14OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4 OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(t-2)^{6}+4(t-1)^{2}(t-2)^{3}-(t-1)^{4}. We also construct a family of graphs containing such spanning trees with chromatic roots converging to t1subscript𝑡1italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{1} from above. We employ the Whitney 22NUMBER:22-switch operation to manage the analysis of an infinite class of chromatic polynomials.

1 Introduction

The chromatic polynomial P⁢(G,t)𝑃𝐺𝑡italic-P OPEN:( italic-G PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)P(G,t) of a graph G𝐺italic-GG is a polynomial with integer coefficients which counts for each non-negative integer t𝑡italic-tt, the number of t𝑡italic-tt-colourings of G𝐺italic-GG. It was introduced by Birkhoff [2] in 1912 for planar graphs, and extended to all graphs by Whitney [9, 10] in 1932. If t𝑡italic-tt is a real number then we say t𝑡italic-tt is a chromatic root of G𝐺italic-GG if P⁢(G,t)=0𝑃𝐺𝑡0italic-P OPEN:( italic-G PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0P(G,t)=0. Thus the numbers 0,1,2,…,χ⁢(G)-1012…𝜒𝐺1NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ID:dots PUNCT:, italic-chi OPEN:( italic-G CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10,1,2,\dots,\chi(G)-1 are always chromatic roots of G𝐺italic-GG and, in fact, the only rational ones. On the other hand it is easy to see that P⁢(G,t)𝑃𝐺𝑡italic-P OPEN:( italic-G PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)P(G,t) is never zero for t∈(-∞,0)𝑡0italic-t RELOP:element-of OPEN:( ADDOP:minus ID:infinity PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)t\in(-\infty,0) and Tutte [8] showed that the same is true for the interval (0,1)01OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(0,1). In 1993 Jackson [5] proved the surprising result that the interval (1,32/27]13227OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:32 MULOP:divide NUMBER:27 CLOSE:](1,32/27] is also zero-free, and found a sequence of graphs whose chromatic roots converge to 32/273227NUMBER:32 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2732/27 from above. Thomassen [6] strengthened this by showing that the set of chromatic roots consists of 00NUMBER:0, 11NUMBER:11, and a dense subset of the interval (32/27,∞)3227OPEN:( NUMBER:32 MULOP:divide NUMBER:27 PUNCT:, ID:infinity CLOSE:)(32/27,\infty).

We say that G𝐺italic-GG is separable if b⁢(G)≥2𝑏𝐺2italic-b OPEN:( italic-G CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:2b(G)\geq 2 and non-separable otherwise. Note that K2subscript𝐾2italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endK_{2} is non-separable. Conjecture 1.1.

There exists ε>0𝜀0italic-varepsilon RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0\varepsilon>0 such that if G𝐺italic-GG is a non-separable graph with a spanning tree of maximum degree 33NUMBER:33, then Q⁢(G,t)>0𝑄𝐺𝑡0italic-Q OPEN:( italic-G PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0Q(G,t)>0 for t∈(1,32/27+ε]𝑡13227𝜀italic-t RELOP:element-of OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:32 MULOP:divide NUMBER:27 ADDOP:plus italic-varepsilon CLOSE:]t\in(1,32/27+\varepsilon].

Barnette [1] proved that a 33NUMBER:33-connected planar graph has a spanning tree of maximum degree 33NUMBER:33. Thus an affirmative answer to Conjecture 1.1 would immediately imply a zero-free interval for the class of 33NUMBER:33-connected planar graphs. Such an interval is known [3] but thought to be far from best possible.

2 Preliminaries

All graphs in this article are simple, that is they have no loops or multiple edges. If u⁢v𝑢𝑣italic-u italic-vuv is an edge of G𝐺italic-GG then G/u⁢v𝐺𝑢𝑣italic-G MULOP:divide italic-u italic-vG/uv denotes the graph obtained by deleting u⁢v𝑢𝑣italic-u italic-vuv and then identifying u𝑢italic-uu with v𝑣italic-vv. This operation is referred to as the contraction of u⁢v𝑢𝑣italic-u italic-vuv. If G𝐺italic-GG is connected, S⊂V⁢(G)𝑆𝑉𝐺italic-S RELOP:subset-of italic-V OPEN:( italic-G CLOSE:)S\subset V(G) and G-S𝐺𝑆italic-G ADDOP:minus italic-SG-S is disconnected, then S𝑆italic-SS is called a cut-set of G𝐺italic-GG. A 22NUMBER:22-cut of G𝐺italic-GG is a cut-set S𝑆italic-SS with |S|=2𝑆2VERTBAR:| italic-S VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals NUMBER:2|S|=2. If S𝑆italic-SS is a cut-set of G𝐺italic-GG and C𝐶italic-CC is a component of G-S𝐺𝑆italic-G ADDOP:minus italic-SG-S, then we say the graph G⁢[V⁢(C)∪S]𝐺delimited-[]𝑉𝐶𝑆italic-G OPEN:[ italic-V OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) ADDOP:union italic-S CLOSE:]G[V(C)\cup S] is an S𝑆italic-SS-bridge of G𝐺italic-GG. If P𝑃italic-PP is a path and x,y∈V⁢(P)𝑥𝑦𝑉𝑃italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y RELOP:element-of italic-V OPEN:( italic-P CLOSE:)x,y\in V(P) then P⁢[x,y]𝑃𝑥𝑦italic-P OPEN:[ italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y CLOSE:]P[x,y] denotes the subpath of P𝑃italic-PP from x𝑥italic-xx to y𝑦italic-yy.

We make repeated use of two fundamental results in the study of chromatic polynomials.

Proposition 2.1 (Deletion-contraction identity).

Let G𝐺italic-GG be a graph and u⁢v𝑢𝑣italic-u italic-vuv be an edge of G𝐺italic-GG. Then

P⁢(G,t)=P⁢(G-u⁢v,t)-P⁢(G/u⁢v,t).𝑃𝐺𝑡𝑃𝐺𝑢𝑣𝑡𝑃𝐺𝑢𝑣𝑡italic-P OPEN:( italic-G PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-P OPEN:( italic-G ADDOP:minus italic-u italic-v PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-P OPEN:( italic-G MULOP:divide italic-u italic-v PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) PERIOD:.P(G,t)=P(G-uv,t)-P(G/uv,t).

Definition 2.1.

Let G𝐺italic-GG be a graph. We say G𝐺italic-GG has property Δnormal-ΔDelta\Delta if the following conditions hold:

  • -

    G𝐺italic-GG is non-separable but not 3-connected.

  • -

    For every 22NUMBER:22-cut {x,y}𝑥𝑦OPEN:{ italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y CLOSE:}\{x,y\}, x⁢y∉E⁢(G)𝑥𝑦𝐸𝐺italic-x italic-y RELOP:not-element-of italic-E OPEN:( italic-G CLOSE:)xy\notin E(G) and G𝐺italic-GG has precisely three {x,y}𝑥𝑦OPEN:{ italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y CLOSE:}\{x,y\}-bridges, all of which are separable.

The property ΔΔDelta\Delta characterises the class of generalised triangles defined by Jackson in [5]. Such graphs can be formed from a triangle by repeatedly replacing an edge by two paths of length 22NUMBER:22.

Lemma 3.2.

Let G𝐺italic-GG be a graph with a 33NUMBER:33-leaf spanning tree T𝑇italic-TT. 3.1 A Zero Free Interval for P⁢(Gi,j,k,t)𝑃subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗𝑘𝑡italic-P OPEN:( italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i PUNCT:, italic-j PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)P(G_{i,j,k},t)

4 Main Result

To prove Theorem 1.2 we shall show that a smallest counterexample has property ΔΔDelta\Delta. In [4], Dong and Koh extracted the essence of the proofs of Thomassen [7] and Jackson [5] and gave a general method to do this. An important part of that method is the following definition and lemma.

Definition 4.1.

Let Gnormal-Gcaligraphic-G\mathcal{G} be a family of graphs. Gnormal-Gcaligraphic-G\mathcal{G} is called splitting-closed if the following conditions hold for each G∈G𝐺normal-Gitalic-G RELOP:element-of caligraphic-GG\in\mathcal{G}.

  • -

    For every complete cut-set C𝐶italic-CC with |C|≤2𝐶2VERTBAR:| italic-C VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:2|C|\leq 2, all C𝐶italic-CC-bridges of G𝐺italic-GG are in 𝒢𝒢caligraphic-G\mathcal{G}.

  • -

    For every 22NUMBER:22-cut {x,y}𝑥𝑦OPEN:{ italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y CLOSE:}\{x,y\} such that x⁢y∉E⁢(G)𝑥𝑦𝐸𝐺italic-x italic-y RELOP:not-element-of italic-E OPEN:( italic-G CLOSE:)xy\not\in E(G), and every {x,y}𝑥𝑦OPEN:{ italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y CLOSE:}\{x,y\}-bridge B𝐵italic-BB, the graphs B+x⁢y𝐵𝑥𝑦italic-B ADDOP:plus italic-x italic-yB+xy and B/x⁢y𝐵𝑥𝑦italic-B MULOP:divide italic-x italic-yB/xy are in 𝒢𝒢caligraphic-G\mathcal{G}.

It is straightforward to check that the family of non-separable graphs with a 33NUMBER:33-leaf spanning tree is splitting-closed. In fact 𝒢ksubscript𝒢𝑘caligraphic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mathcal{G}_{k} is splitting-closed for all k≥2𝑘2italic-k RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:2k\geq 2.
